For Deputy Minister.
Bishop
The Rt.Rev.Henry D.Martin, D.D.

Mr. R.A. Hoey
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I now wish to nominate Miss Mildred Hitchcock as teacher at the South School on Fort a la Corne Reserve. I have given Miss Hitchcock's qualifications in a previous letter, and I would like to add that she is most anxious to help in Indian work. I have every confidence that she would do good and faithful work on a reserve. I have not heard from you regarding the transfer of Mr. L. Ahenakew from the South School to the North School at Fort a la Corne and of course Miss Hitchcock's nomination is subject to your agreement of the proposed change.

Faithfully yours,

(Sgd.) Henry D. Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, July 17, 1945.

Mr. H.J. McLeod, Acting Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.

Ottawa, April 16th, 1947.

Mr. N.J. McLeod, Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.

In your letter of February 3rd, 1947, you stated that Mrs. Burbridge would begin duties at the James Smith North Indian Day School on April 8th.

We have now received a staff questionnaire from her in which she states that she commenced duties on March 31st.

Please let me know if the latter date is correct so that we can place her name on the pay list.

Bernard Neary,
Mupt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: James Smith Indian Day School, No. 608.

The Department has received and accepted the resignation of the teacher, Mrs. Ida McLeod, effective January 1, 1945, and no further payment of salary should be made to her after that date.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa,
December 15, 1944.

Mr. N. J. McLeod, Acting Indian Agent, Duck Lake, Saskatchewan.

I am advised by Bishop Martin that Mrs. Ida McLeod, teacher of the James Smith Day School, finds it necessary to give up her duties at the end of the current month.

Please find attached T.D.l forms and staff questionnaire on her.

for Deputy Minister.

HPN/RAD
Ottawa, 22 November 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: James Smith Indian Day School No. 608

With reference to our memorandum of Nov. 9th, please note that we have received and accepted the resignation of the teacher, Mr. Frank C. Day, effective December 1, 1946.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, 30 November 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: James Smith Indian Day School
No. 608

With further reference to our memorandum of Nov. 22nd, we have just been informed that Mr. Dey has been persuaded to remain at this school until the Christmas holidays.

Therefore his resignation will now take place on Jan. 1, 1947. Will you please arrange to retain him on the salary roll until that time?

Reference my letter #349-15 MM of March 5th 1934, and your letter #109-4-5 of the 12th idem, re the serving of a hot drink at the four Day Schools in this Agency, I have the honour to ask if it is the wish of the Department that this be carried on during summer months, if so I would ask for authority to purchase sufficient Sugar, Cocoa and Drimilk for the three months ending June 30th and for the month of September, when a further requisition will be made for the winter months.

Dear Mr. Smith:

In conversation with Miss Jean McKay, Prince Albert, the other day her correspondence with you, with regard to our pre-mission tests, was referred to. I suggested to her that, since I was more familiar with the situation leading up to this correspondence, it might be well for me to write to you in the matter in order that any misunderstanding might be readily smoothed out.

May I refer to the organization under whose guidance our premission tests are arranged? Three inspectorates combine in the scheme; namely, Kinistino, Shell Lake, and Prince Albert.

Davis being the agent. Some teachers in his agency have again approached me to write you that they may have the same privilege as the schools in the Duck Lake Agency. Three schools in Mr. Davis' agency have approached me, viz.: Ahpahkakoops, Wm. Watts, or Sturgeon Lake, and Little Red.

Acting on the intimation of your letter may I suggest that you refer this matter to Mr. Davis, Agent, Leask.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Inspectorial Promotion Test for Day Schools.

I beg to advise that I am in receipt of a letter from Jean McKay, Secretary Treasurer, Examination Committee Prince Albert, enclosing an account for June examination papers for the Fort a la Corne South Day School, applied for by Mrs. E.M. Siddons, Teacher, amounting to $2.00.

I find that this organization supplied examination papers to the John Smith's Day School for June examinations last June.

I recommend that these forms be provided for the forementioned Day Schools, also for the Fort a la Corne North Day School, and request authority to do so.

I have the honour to be

Sir

There is sufficient experienced Indian labour on the reserve to do the work.

The Agent also request that if funds are available outside repairs be made to the Fort a La Corne North Indian Day School. This building is in bad need of re-painting. I also notice that the South School on the same reserve could do with a re-painting but at the present time it is in better shape than the school north of it.

EX'D.

Mr. S.H. Simpson, Indian Agent, Duck Lake, Sask.

Mr. Christianson has forwarded to this office a copy of your letter to him of April 19, with reference to repairs required at the Fort a la Corne North Day School. The Department approves an expenditure of $46.15 for material and $40 for labour.

R.A.

Mr. N.J. McLeod, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Duck Lake, Sask.

James Smith Indian Day School

With reference to your requisitions of April 28th, the Department approves an expenditure of $63.00 for repairs to the James Smith Day School and dining room and also an expenditure of $91.00 for repairs to the teacher's residence at the same school as outlined on the requisitions which you forwarded.

Funds are not available for painting the exterior of the school.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.
